author: Boone Bergsma
title: Stiff Money | Crowdlending PaaS
description: Getting a stable Annual Percentage Yield (APY) on the assets your holding is hard. And getting a loan to buy a home is even harder.

assessments.note: While the idea to use ADA staking rewards to subsidize housing is a good concept, this proposal does not adress that aim well: The rates for the people lending homes are much higher than typical US mortgage rates, making this offer only attractive to people that will not be able obtaining a mortgage, for example due to a poor financial situation. For those people however, such astronomically high anual rates are a very hard to cope with expense which have the potential do drive them even more into poverty, so qualifying this into doing something good as it is done in the proposal is difficult. As the rates in this business model are set, it is rather a model to earn ADA holders a higher APY than they would get by regular staking and additionally provide profit to the operators of the crowdlending platform at the cost of high rates for the people renting the homes. In order for the proposal to make a worthy addition to the DeFi-ecosystem of Cardano, the thoughts behind it's financial setup need to be made more transparent in order for it to be justified. On first thought, the proposal would be better if it introduced a system where the staking rewards would be used to discount the loan rates instead of making them more expensive.

This proposal meets the general requirements of the challenge. There appears to be significant desire for innovative financing mechanisms in the defi space and this proposal would be an interesting option. The proposal would benefit from a better discussion on what its success would look like. Is there a threshold that is being sought? (e.g. number of people using service, new Dapp users, particular level of value being locked in)?

The proposal seems to be very focussed on addressing providing DeFi options in the space. It would be interesting to understand if there had been intentions from the proposer to further develop the business model/tech if the proposal was successful and achieved it's MVP, launch etc.

The problem statement has an unsubstantiated and subjective claim. Some DeFi protocols currently have some of the largest APYs in the entire global financial market, this is easily verified on DeFi analytics websites such as https://defirate.com/lend/ or https://defiyield.info/

The proposal is to develop an MVP, so it will not meet the metrics established in the Challenge Brief and is not in line with the challenge.
It is a DeFi project that addresses a financial need.
This is a single idea, not scaling up the DeFi ecosystem. Thus does not address the challenge.

I don't think this financial product of Leasing to Own as opposed to Renting to Own is novel enough to curb the first home ownership issues around the world. I was a home flipper myself and the profit mindset took me many years to shake. Let's build a better system outside ownership/profit/lease model.. Realestate sector is ripe for disruption

Given the small amount of money being requested to develop a MVP, it is  likely that this proposal would be implemented successfully. The proposer's experience is related but I'd appreciate more details on the technical side of it. What skills/workers are needed to develop the MVP? 

More details are also needed on the inner workings of the Stiff Money operations. The presentation deck that is linked to within the proposal could break down each step more clearly. For example, if a person stakes with the Stiff Money stake pool how does this affect their ability to liquidate? How long is the staking term for? Are there several options or is it a one size fits all scenario? These types of details will help the clarity of the overall proposal, as well as voters when trying to determine whether it could be successful.

The proposer seems to have some experience in real estate. The financial calculations behind the interest rates are intransparent and don't match up to US mortgage rates which will make the proposal likely to fail due to lack of interes on the side of people using it to get loans for housing. In addition to this, the introduction of another currency that will have a low market cap and thus be prone to volatility is another factor that makes the proposal less secure. There is no rationale giving for the budget demanded.

Whilst I was able to follow the slide deck, I feel each slide raised more questions for me. Who would ensure Stiff Money operated in good faith (given we currently do not have Smart Contracts)? How will $DEED work from a tokenomics perspective, who controls the supply? It feels slightly like the proposal jumps from a high level 'what could be' to 'we will build an MVP, thanks' which isn't totally connected with more detail.

There is no information about the qualification of the team in the development of smart contracts (the proposal requires smart contracts to allow a decentralized loan).

There is no detailed plan for how dapp will deliver a 10% APY yield. Dapp is promising a fixed yield of 10% APY, and does not describe in detail the economic model and the viability of the business of buying and selling real estate.

There is no budget breakdown.

The risks involved in the use of dapp were not described (unlike staking, in the case of this proposal, ADAs would leave the user's wallet and remain in a smart contract or be lent, this brings risks that can make the financial model unfeasible. With ADA staking, although the APY is around 5%, the risks are extremely low, in the case of loans the risk increases and mantaining the APY at 10% may not dynamically reflect the risks.
There is no information regarding detailing the relevant experience of the team behind the project.

No details on how the 10% APY will be funded. Is this a Ponzi scheme? People won't pay 10% p.a. on a home loan, interest rates are way below that in the developed world. Are you proposing the lender is actually taking equity in the properties bought?

As before, I feel nervous about combining the primordial sense of home, belonging and security with 'crazy DeFi profits'. Its time to make RealFi Dapps. I feel nervous about associating landlordship in disguise with Cardano and adding to extractive mindset and agenda in the world. P2P lending could be a noble activity if our community were to somehow share profits collectively. Otherwise it looks like extractive legacy project to me which I don't believe will make the world a better place.

Given that this proposal represents only stage 1 of many likely stages, it is very feasible that this project will be achievable. Also, the low budget of this proposal presents minimal risk to the catalyst community with the potential for high returns. In order to increase the score I'd like to see the proposal go into more depth about what form the MVP will take and how this will be measured. 

The proposal could also do a better job at breaking down the funding request into smaller pieces so voters know exactly what the money will be spent on. 

The proposal could be strengthened by providing additional information on how it gets to it's yield numbers. For example, if the Stiff Money app is conducted through a stake pool, what will that mean for saturation limits and the diminishing returns when saturated? Can this be clarified? Could this affect the success of the overall project, why/why not?
In the attached deck there is also mention of using the profits to purchase housing but it is less clear how each of the components work together and what happens if people don't live up to their end of the smart contracts. Would there need to be an eviction/enforcement arm? 
Expanding on these details could increase the likelihood of successful implementation and sends the message that these things have been thought through to the voters.

As mentioned in the notes about, the financial model is intransparent and seems off without further explanation. There is no plan about the actual implementation of the platform (e.G. milestones) and no rationale for the budget. I recommend to publish this with a more detailed plan for implentation and calculations or at least explanations of the financial model behind it.
The proposal doesn't address features or milestones which could be used to ensure the proposer is on track with the project. It's more blind faith, insert coin, wait and see.

There is no detailed plan, no roadmap, no milestones, no metrics, no KPIs, no budget breakdown and there is no information about the team's experience in developing smart contracts.

I recommend detailing the proposal to allow auditability.
There is little information about the implementation. Borrow money from what institutions to buy real state?
No plan on how this will be implemented, how the economics work, or how it will be marketed. No milestones or goals.

Well without dealing with evictions on defaulting the loans and all other such measures that deeply contradict my personal sense of community and human rights, I do not see this project having measurable outcomes that would agree with my Commonist standpoint. Even as a Libertarian I would not think that making large profits on DeFi housing is a new idea. It broke the gates of Babylon did it not?

solution: Stiff Money offers depositors of ADA and other cryptos a 10% APY. And offers homebuyers a no-down-payment lease to own smart contract loan.
experience: Went to college for Real Estate, has flipped homes for profit, and is currently investing in the development of Stiff Money's platform now.
